title: I'm getting sued by my credit card company&am thinking of filing bankruptcy, does my wife need to file bankruptcy as well?
question: I want to discharge the debt&don't want the credit card company to go after my wife. Also, my wife has a Green Card&I don't want this affecting her citizenship.
question_tags: Child support,Immigration,Immigrants and credit cards,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Citizenship application
answers:
You can file on your own, but as mentioned, the household income and expenses are all part of what you have to disclose. Assets may be an important aspect of the filing too. She may or may not have liability or community liability on the debt. This can be important under some circumstances. There is a lot more information needed to really answer your question.

No matter what you hear on this site, you should see a local experienced bankruptcy attorney to discuss all of the facts and to get advice. It is almost never a good idea to file without an attorney.

You are allowed to file by yourself. The court does not require spouses to file together; however, the court does require considering all household income. The court cannot require that your spouse pay your debts, but since she should be contributing to the household, they want to get a full picture of avaliable income. Additionally, if any of the debts are joint debts, you may need to consider having your wife file. Your bankruptcy only impacts your obligations. So, if you both owe a credit card and just you file, she will still be left with the full bill. I will also tell you, if she does have substantial debts, you should seriously consider filing together. Most lawyers do not charge too much more for both you and your wife filing bankruptcy on the same petition. But, if you file and then she files, it is two separate cases with usually double the fees.

As for your wife’s citizenship application, a bankruptcy should have no impact. You can review the application for citizenship on the UCSIS website. Only debts that can have an impact are tax debts and child support.

Good luck.
No. You can file without her. But her income, if any needs to be disclosed as part of the Means Test.

No, she does not. However, her income if any is considered to see whether the two of you are above the "median income" for a family size the same as yours. If the household income is over a set amount, you will have to do the "means test." It can be simple or ugly depending on the income. Social security is NOT counted for the means test but everything else is.

There is another issue. If you file bankruptcy without her, not only will all of your separate property is an asset in the "bankruptcy estate" but all community property that the two of you have no matter whose name is on the title. As an example, if she bought a car in her marriage and put it into her name, and she paid it off with her earnings during the marriage, it is still community property. That is because her income belongs to both of you and therefore the car was bought with community income. You need to know what is community property and what is not.

Bankruptcy is not about filling out papers. It is about seeing to it that the client does not step on a landmine. It is easy to do exactly that when you do not know the law.

Whether your wife files with you or not may depend on issues that are too long to explain here. It also depends on her debts and the likelihood that she could lose some separate property such as inheritances or assets that she owned before the marriage or obtained from separate property. That will take a review of your assets and hers to see what will be protected.

Do yourself a huge favor and see a quality bankruptcy attorney to find out what can be done for you and what is protected. Your case would be filed in the Bankruptcy Court in Sacramento. I would recommend you find a quality bankruptcy attorney by looking at Avvo's ratings for Sacramento attorneys.

You could also look at the CA State bar website for a Certified Bankruptcy Law Specialist in Sacramento. Most attorneys will give you are free initial consultation. I have provided a link to the state bar below.

Another potential source for finding a good attorney would be through a search of the National Association of Consumer Bankruptcy Attorneys (NACBA.org) to find a good local attorney. Again, I have provided a link below.
No matter how good an attorney is rated, if you are not comfortable with the attorney when you meet, move on to another attorney. Also, if the attorney uses a paralegal to do the initial appointment, move on because you are just a number and a dollar sign. If this is how you are treated when they are trying to get your money, you can be certain it is not going to get better after they get your money.

Do NOT use an attorney that does anything other than bankruptcy and consumer law and/or foreclosure law. Part-time bankruptcy attorneys are, sadly, never expert enough to do the job right. This is a specialized field and you should go with an attorney who practices solely in that specialty. Choose based on skill rather than price. A bad attorney will cost you way more in the long run. Never hire to veterinarian's assistant to do brain surgery on you and never hire a non-specialist to do a specialists job. Get the right attorney to begin with.

I hope this helps you.

http://members.calbar.ca.gov/search/ls_search.aspx

http://www.nacba.org/find-an-attorney
